title: RBS bosses ordered to go out and meet small firms
text:

Sun, Aug 9, 2015, 22:43 BST - UK Markets closed RBS bosses ordered to go out and meet small firms By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 3 minutes 8 seconds ago 345.50 -3.40 
Executives lost touch with reality before the financial crash, and the bank’s commercial banking chief says meeting SMEs is the best way to stay focused 
Senior (Other OTC: SNIRF - news ) managers at Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) have been ordered to meet more small firms to make sure they stay focused on customer service and do not repeat the mistakes of the pre-crash years, when they “forgot what they were there for,” in a new rule from the bank’s commercial and private banking chief. 
Alison Rose heads the division, and wants the top brass to follow her example of meeting two or three small businesses per week to understand what customers need from RBS. 
“I make all of my executive committee and myself own customer relationships, because it is important to stay connected with businesses,” she said, adding that this includes working through the SME’s books and making decisions on loan applications. 
“I think if you’re an executive and you’re not spending time with customers, you become completely disconnected from what the business is all about. The whole point is, banks forgot what they were there for if you only ever see things through the filter of a large corporate, you don’t get a real feel, whereas if you go and sit down with a customer, they are not shy about saying, “I don’t like this” or “there is a problem here.”” 
RBS is Britain’s biggest lender to businesses, but its reputation has taken a series of knocks in recent years, with customers claiming compensation for interest rate swap mis-selling , and investigations into the bank’s Global Restructuring Group which was accused of profiting from small firms’ financial problems. 
“I think we’ve got a long way to go in improving customer service and the trust and the advocacy,” she said. 
Ms Rose said she is sending all 3,500 relationship managers at the bank on a new set of training courses working on the basics of banking from credit risk through to culture and behaviour, as well as making more staff specialise in specific sectors. 
She (Munich: SOQ.MU - news ) is also taking the course, along with the executive committee. 
Another part of that is to show customers that she is not a distant figure at head office turning down loans on a whim. 
“I’m quite ordinary, and I think that is quite important, that they don’t think there is a big bad boss up at central office opining on their business,” said Ms Rose. 
She was speaking after the government began selling down the shares acquired in the bank bailouts of 2008 and 2009. 
Chancellor George Osborne said the sale of a 5.4pc stake in the bank for £2.1bn indicates it is now “time for RBS to rebuild itself as a commercial bank, no longer reliant on the state, but serving the working people of Britain.” 
The first stage of the privatisation came after the bank reported profits of £293m in the second quarter of 2015, as RBS continues to struggle with the costs of compensating customers for past mis-selling.
